Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2010 12:36PM tuffgirl wrote: Hi i noticed this too - but this is not new. When i was a teen (i<m my forties) my friend's mother had it. regrettably she ended up with you guessed it bone mets including to the scalp.  My friend mentions this to me on occasion still wondering if it in part stopped the chemo from effecting where it should. My cancer agency started with gloves though because they felt mets to the hands were low and that would possibly stop the neuropathy but no scalp things. and merry christmas!
Posts.Title: Article on Keeping Your Hair During Chemo-Cold Cap Pure lago

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 07:33PM tuffgirl wrote: Hi you are really in a rough way and I wish I knew what to say.  I learned I had BC not officially but found the lump right after surfing in hawaii.  I wiped out really good on black rock and so was in the bathroom under this  tropical light checking out to see where else i was bloodied when i noticed - hey that doesn't look right and did a self exam. I immediately called my husband back in Canada( I was on a business trip) and he arranged for an appointment on my return immediately but the rest of the trip I was just kind of going through the motions. I continued with the snorkeling etc, in my time off but my mind was going wild. If you have trip insurance? or could you accept learning of it and using a great break to accept it? like conniemae spoke of, or maybe fingers crossed get great news? take care
Posts.Title: What would you do? Biopsy scheduled 4 days before vacation... shabby6485 awb

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 10:04PM tuffgirl wrote: Hi there! It was in 2007 that I was told the nasty 3 words. Heavy sigh! anyway my oncologist was never Miss Congeniality and seemed to happily tell me my stats were nasty (gee thanks! needless to say I have a new onc!) anyway just to say that life does go on post the big C !!!!  I even go for day (s) (that's new, it used to be day only) not even thinking about it - I know that seems impossible now, but trust and believe me. it will happen. I'm not an optimist but have tried to learn to be one. All the best

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 12:12AM tuffgirl wrote: Hi Diana I'm so glad! it's like going through this process though is like losing lives... In Canada they only check you as follows 1. mamo or other screen MRI 2.core biopsy or other depending 3. after confirmation then blood work and liver U\s 4.lung X-ray 5. nuclear bone scan assuming you are not in situ  no brain checking at all. Unless you have symptoms then no other checking AT ALL I'm so glad for your findings!
